Using HTTP POST to send commands to non-HTTP services (SMTP, FTP, Redis)

q: Can you CSRF a Redis server?
o: Yes, if exposed on localhost and browser allows port (rare now), command injection via POST body
Similar to Redis (UDP/TCP), injecting commands via forged requests
If unprotected, browser can POST JSON queries/updates (Data modification/Leak)
`csurf` (deprecated), now recommends tiny-csrf or manual implementation
Attacker on subdomain can overwrite cookie (Cookie Tossing), setting it to match their token
Allows trusted scripts to load other scripts (focus on XSS, but relevant to avoiding CSRF bypass via XSS)
Restricts where a page can navigate (Mitigates some CSRF/Open Redirect)
Restricts URLs to which forms can be submitted (Defense against data exfil via forged forms)
Prevents forms on YOUR site submitting to attacker site (Reverse CSRF/Exfil), not attacker submitting to YOU
Using open redirect to bypass strict Referer/Origin checks (redirect originates from trusted domain)

q: How does Open Redirect bypass header checks?
o: Initial request is to trusted domain (passes check), which redirects to sensitive action (headers might persist or checks skipped)
Any user content on subdomain (e.g. user.site.com) can be used to attack parent (Cookie Tossing)
List of domains where users can register subdomains (e.g. .co.uk,github.io). Affects cookie scope

q: Why is Public Suffix List important for CSRF?
o: Prevents setting cookies for top-level domains (e.g. cookie for .com)
Old Flash vulnerability allowed setting Referer
Browser fetching favicon (GET request) - potentially triggering logout or state change if path is mapped
Link expalnders/bots making requests to generate preview cards (GET CSRF)
Attacker using headless browser script to automate CSRF (more capabilities than simple form)
RSS reader making requests to feed items (GET CSRF)
Fetching external images/links in calendar events
Loading external images in webmail (GET CSRF + tracking)
If 404 page reflects input or allows script, can become vector
Preserves method (POST stays POST) on redirect. Dangerous if Open Redirect exists
Usually changes POST to GET (protects against POST CSRF accidentally)
Manipulating URL fragment/state to trigger client actions
Prevents CSRF in OpenID Connect flow (binding request to browser session)
Prevents Replay attacks and associates ID Token with client session

q: What is 'PKCE' (Proof Key for Code Exchange)?
o: OAuth extension for public clients, prevents authorization code interception (and CSRF)
Yes, `state` is still recommended but PKCE adds strong correlation
Attribute in SAML Response matching the ID of the Request (Anti-CSRF/Replay)
Placing CSRF middleware AFTER body parser or route handler (Protection fails)

q: What implies 'CSRF Middleware' must be before 'Routes'?
o: Middleware must intercept/validate BEFORE action executes
Devs excluding /api/* from CSRF thinking it is safe (it might not be)
If app allows action with no session (public), CSRF is technically 'Click fraud' or 'Spam'
Forcing user to checkout (buying items) if payment details saved/session active
Triggering print dialog (Annoyance) or printer exploits
Web Bluetooth API abuse (if permissions granted) to control devices
WebUSB API abuse to send commands to connected USB devices
WebNFC API abuse to write/read tags
WebMIDI API abuse to control instruments/sysex
Using Gamepad API to fingerprint or track (less direct CSRF)
